text:
‚ÄúIs there anyone who ever remembers changing their mind from the paint on a sign?‚Äù - John Mayer

Not me.

And I‚Äôll bet you haven‚Äôt either.

Because it takes more than a protestor‚Äôs sign to change someone‚Äôs belief.

So, what DOES it take?

Emotion + proof.

That‚Äôs it.

The world is shaped by what you believe is true and what you believe isn't true. You‚Äôre probably stuck because you find comfort in your beliefs. You lock yourself in and that stops you from reaching your potential.

You start coping, not creating.

The only way to break out of that cycle is to change what you believe is possible. Then, and only then, will you be able to change your habits and actions.

And the quickest way to change is to see someone doing what you thought was not possible.

Case in point‚Ä¶

On May 6, 1954, British athlete Roger Bannister made history by becoming the first person to run a mile in under four minutes, clocking in at 3:59.4 at Iffley Road Track in Oxford.

Bannister's record stood for only 46 days before Australian John Landy broke it with a time of 3:57.9. Since then, over 1,700 athletes have also run sub-four-minute miles, demonstrating how Bannister's achievement opened the floodgates for future runners.

In my life, the best way I‚Äôve found to break my limiting beliefs around business and personal achievement is community.

Joining the right communities can SHATTER what you thought was possible.

Why?

Because, in the right communities, you will find people who have achieved more than you ever imagined. And they are sharing their stories about how they go there.

Instantly, all of your excuses are worthless.

Because here is someone, probably a lot like you, that is PROVING your theories wrong. 

All that stuff IS POSSIBLE.

It‚Äôs not impossible, you‚Äôre just in the wrong echo chambers.

Find the right ones.

comments.text: Swanagan Ray These days it's hard to not be caught up in an echo chamber. But finding the right community can change everything. A lot of times, it's just about finding the right people.

text:
Retirement was invented for people who hate their jobs.

But if you build a life around things you actually enjoy‚Ä¶

Why would you ever want to stop?

I don‚Äôt want to sit on a beach for 30 years.

I want to write, build, teach, and explore until I drop.

The game is finding work that energizes you instead of drains you.

The kind that compounds your skills, expands your network, and makes your kids proud.

Not because you ‚Äúhave to.‚Äù

Because you get to.

Never retire; work on stuff you like forever.

That‚Äôs my plan.

comments.text: What an inspiring perspective. If you love what you do, retirement is a foreign concept.

author.occupation: Organizational Development Consultant | Helping Organizations and Leaders Reduce Turnover, Transform Workplace Culture, and Develop Leadership Strategies for Sustainable Success

comments.text:
My dad retired 12 years ago and never looked back. The last 2 years of work, he hated it. He owned his own business, but regulations, new tax laws, and other changes to his industry made it not fun. Now he is having fun. He LOVES retirement. 

I used to look forward to it, too. Working a 9to5, of course I couldn't wait. Now, though, I'm building something I like and enjoy. Even though I could retire in 15 ish years, I don't want to. I want to see this thing grow and see where it leads.

text:
Comfort is just calcification in disguise.

Every time you choose comfort over growth, something inside you hardens.

Not all at once.
Not loud or obvious.
But slowly.

One skipped workout.
One more project you don‚Äôt speak up in.
One ‚Äúwe‚Äôve always done it this way‚Äù you don‚Äôt challenge.

Until your edge dulls and your curiosity dies.

Comfort feels good, right up to the moment you realize it‚Äôs a trap.

Progress doesn‚Äôt come from safety.

It comes from stretch. From struggle. From choosing friction.

So ask yourself:

Where have I gotten too comfortable?

Then go shake the snow globe.

comments.text: So true. Comfort might feel safe, but real growth starts when we step out of it!

comments.text: "Progress doesn't come from safety." Pretty powerful words. And true. Playing it safe will keep you where you are, but it won't let you grow.

text:
One of the best decisions I ever made was to switch from Planet Fitness to an expensive gym. 

Serious people go to serious gyms. 

Being around people like this will inspire you to get better by osmosis. 

And it applies just as much to every other part of your life, not just the gym. 

If you sit in the sun, it‚Äôs hard not to get warm.

Who matters more than what. 

Find your tribe.

comments.text: You are who you surround yourself with. That's why it's important to build up a great team. You can't do it alone.
Not all gyms are created equal. The same is true for all communities. Being inspired is a powerful force.

text:
Stop giving your best people more work.

They‚Äôre not your default backup plan.

They‚Äôre not your ‚Äúfix it‚Äù button.
They‚Äôre not infinite.

Top performers make it look easy, so you assume they can take more.

But high output ‚â† unlimited capacity.

Every extra project you throw their way comes with a hidden cost:
‚ñ† Focus gets obliterated
‚ñ† Which causes motivation to erode
‚ñ† And then resentment builds to a critical mass

Until one day, the high performer is doing stuff that they don't like and have no energy for, causing them to disengage.

Not because they couldn‚Äôt do the work.

But because no one protected their energy.

Great leadership isn‚Äôt about maximizing every ounce of effort.

It‚Äôs about knowing when to shield your best people so they can keep showing up as their best.

Protect the fire. 

Don‚Äôt burn it out.

text:
Ever look for a spark of inspiration and come up with jack squat?

Bad feeling.

But the hard truth is that you need to stop looking for it, and just create it.

If there‚Äôs a gap, fill it. If there‚Äôs a missing perspective, offer it.

Sometimes you have to create the stuff you want to see.

Reminds me of the time I was 7.

With a name like Swanagan, my Grandma was having trouble finding me one of those old cards (you the ones with your name and supposed meaning), so she just had it made custom.

She probably paid way too much to get me a card with my name on it so I didn‚Äôt feel like the odd man out with my brothers and sister. 

But she saw something missing and fixed it.

And that‚Äôs something we can all take a cue from. 

You have to ask yourself: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs missing?‚Äù

Because there‚Äôs definitely something missing.

It‚Äôs that gnawing feeling tugging at the back of your mind. What angle do you see that no one else does?

Start there.

That doesn‚Äôt mean flooding your feed with posts just for the sake of posting, it means sharing ideas you‚Äôd genuinely want to read.

If you can‚Äôt get behind your own ideas, why should anyone else?

Experiment, refine, and get as much feedback as you can.

Each iteration you closer to the authentic voice that only you can put into the ether.

There‚Äôs only one you.

Get weird.

Create the spark.

comments.text: Swanagan Ray When you don't see what you want, make it happen. Embracing that mindset not only uncovers new paths but builds your unique legacy.

text:
The best leaders I've encountered understand this distinction: 

People thrive when they're led with clarity, empathy, and vision...

Not micromanaged through every step. 

Most new leaders confuse activity with impact.

They spend their days buried in tasks, tweaking details. 

But your real job isn't to manage processes; it's to lead people.

Automate or delegate processes relentlessly, and free your attention to ignite human potential. 

That‚Äôs how meaningful growth happens.

text:
Life is too short to spend it chasing things that don't matter.

Your title will be forgotten. 
Your salary will be spent. 
Your awards will collect dust.

But the impact you have on people will last forever.

So here's my advice:
Focus on who you're becoming, not just what you're achieving.

Invest in relationships, not just results.

Be the person others remember for the right reasons.

Because at the end of the day, who you are is all that really matters.

And who you are is measured by how you treat the people around you.

Start today. Be intentional about who you want to be.

The what will follow.

text:
You‚Äôre not ‚Äúbusy.‚Äù 

You‚Äôre buffering.

Every meeting. 
Every scroll. 
Every ‚Äúyes.‚Äù

Default mode.

And default mode is dangerous because it feels like you‚Äôre doing something, but you‚Äôre not deciding to do anything that matters.

It's a bad feeling... letting other people and situations dictate literally your whole life. 

But it doesn't have to be that way.

If there's no conscious intention behind the action, stop doing it.

That project you‚Äôre dragging along out of obligation?
That podcast you play just to fill the silence?
That gym routine that isn‚Äôt moving the needle anymore?

Pause. Ask yourself:

What am I actually trying to accomplish here?

Is this still aligned with where I want to go?

Intention is the gatekeeper of progress.

Without it, you're just sleepwalking through someone else‚Äôs priorities.

Clarity is a competitive advantage.

Audit your actions. 
Keep the ones with intent. 
Cut the rest.

comments.text: Bufferring through life isn‚Äôt hustle. It‚Äôs just noise you don‚Äôt need.
So true. Busy doesn‚Äôt mean productive unless there‚Äôs real intention behind it!

text:
Quitting is a text. 
A Slack message. 
One awkward conversation where you explain why this isn't working anymore.

Building is showing up at 5 AM when your alarm goes off and everything in you wants to stay in bed. 

Building is the tenth revision of that landing page. 

The fifteenth take of that video. 

The hundredth cold email that gets ignored.

I've learned this the hard way. Multiple times.

When I was learning guitar, I sucked. Really sucked. Someone told me I'd never win anything. So I practiced scales until my fingers bled. Won two state championships.

When I was overweight, someone called me fat. Could've quit right there. Instead, I did the reps. Lost 50 pounds.

The difference between the people who make it and the people who don't isn't talent. It's not connections. It's not even luck.

It's the willingness to do the boring work when nobody's watching. 

When there's no immediate reward. 

When you can't post about it for engagement.

You know what nobody sees? 

The failed launches. 
The products that flopped. 
The newsletters that started with three subscribers. 
The code that broke everything. 

But here's what I've figured out: every rep counts. 

Even the ones that feel pointless. 
Especially the ones that feel pointless.

Because success isn't about the moment you "make it." It's about becoming the person who does the work regardless. 

The person who shows up when showing up is the last thing they want to do.

Quitting is easy. It's a decision you make once.

Building is hard. It's a decision you make every single day.

Choose accordingly.

comments.text: Building is choosing the tough road every day. It's easy to start, but hard to finish. We must choose to build...not once but many times every day. Swanagan Ray

profile.occupation: Follow for posts about business, leadership, and writing. Director, Operational Technology.

comments.text: You nailed it. Quitting is easy, showing up is what counts. It's that boring work that adds up Swanagan Ray

text:
Great leaders don't just solve problems, they choose the right problems to solve. 

Eisenhower‚Äôs matrix is the one way I've found that helps me figure out the right problems:

> Important + Urgent: Solve immediately, but beware, if you live here, your system is broken.

> Important + Not Urgent: Schedule these like sacred rituals. Your future depends on them.

> Urgent + Not Important: Delegate ruthlessly. Your energy belongs elsewhere.

> Neither Important nor Urgent: Cut aggressively. Your sanity thanks you.

Remember, the goal is effectiveness. 

Focus on outcomes, and let that be the lens you use to prioritize into these buckets. 

‚Üì ‚Üì ‚Üì

text:
There's also 3 levels to leadership.

Level 1: Not knowing how to play.

You‚Äôve got the sticks (the title), but you're scared to hit anything. Meetings drift. 

Decisions stall. Momentum dies.

Level 2: Playing everything.

You fill every space with noise. You‚Äôre the loudest in every conversation, involved in every detail. Busy but your team struggles to find a rhythm.

Level 3: Knowing when NOT to play.
This is mastery. You only hit when it matters. You create space so others can shine. 

Silence becomes power.

Here‚Äôs the truth I‚Äôve learned leading teams:

Most leaders think Level 2 is where the magic happens. But Level 3 is where teams actually win.

Great leadership is about creating the rhythm that everyone can follow.

comments.text: Level 3 is the sweet spot! It's not about controlling everything, but creating space for others to thrive and lead.

author.occupation: Fractional Operator. Systems Thinker. I build products that sell themselves.

comments.text: This is a great analogy for leadership. I never thought about it in this context. It takes practice and great humility to get to level 3. Swanagan Ray

text:
The best leaders I‚Äôve worked with all had one thing in common.

Not titles. Not Ivy League degrees.

They were empathetic. Relentlessly kind.

Even when they didn‚Äôt have to be.
Especially when they didn‚Äôt have to be.

As a new leader, it's easy to think your value comes from being decisive, sharp, or efficient.

But people don‚Äôt remember how fast you responded to emails.

They remember how you made them feel when they messed up.
How you treated them when you had power and they didn‚Äôt.

Kindness doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre soft.

It means you're strong enough to lead without ego.
It means you can correct without crushing.
Coach without condescending.
Give feedback without taking someone‚Äôs identity apart.

Anyone can be tough when things go wrong. But the leaders people want to follow are the ones who choose kindness when it‚Äôs not convenient.

Start there. The rest gets easier.

comments.text: Kindness is a strength. You can choose it at any moment, whether convenient or not. Make it your default setting. Makes a world of difference.
Couldn't agree more Swanagan Ray. Real leadership is about emotional strength, not just strategic smarts. Kindness is a power move, not a weakness.

text:
‚ÄúTradition is just peer pressure from dead people.‚Äù 

A ton of people confuse progress with permission.

They wait for a nod from a boss, a degree from a school, or a ‚Äúbest practice‚Äù from someone who hasn‚Äôt done anything new in 20 years.

But here‚Äôs the thing...

The people who built the systems you're operating in? They were winging it.

No one gave them permission. They just started.

So why are you still waiting?

You don‚Äôt need a formal greenlight to do something new.

You can just do things. 

Just because something's always been done that way doesn't mean that it SHOULD be done that way. 

The key is to understand WHY that thing was done in the first place. Once you understand, you can take it back to first principles and figure out if a change is needed.

comments.text: Swanagan, progress starts when we stop waiting and start thinking for ourselves. Thanks for sharing this!

text:
Most of what you chase isn't real.

Status games. Fancy titles. Algorithmic approval.

It‚Äôs all noise. 

Distraction disguised as ambition.

Meanwhile, your energy is tanking. Your joy is leaking. And you wonder why progress feels like pushing a boulder uphill in the rain.

Here‚Äôs the unlock:
Optimize for energy and joy.

Everything else is a psyop.

No, really.

Life is an energy game. 

When you're energized, you move better.
When you're joyful, you create better.
When you're both, you become unstoppable.

Forget productivity hacks.

Start with this question instead:
What gives me energy and what drains it?

Then rewire accordingly.

text:
Most people suck at listening.

Because they think it just means saying nothing.

Wrong.

It's so much more. 

The best listeners I know turn ordinary conversations into a trust-building exercise.

Here‚Äôs their playbook:
> Full attention, zero distractions.
> Listen without scripting a reply.
> Nods and verbal cues that signal real understanding.
> Open-ended, probing questions that pull deeper insights.
> Restating points clearly, confirming understanding, and connecting genuinely.

Pick just one of these five areas and ruthlessly practice it in every conversation today. 

Tomorrow, pick another.

Huge ROI activity. 

What would you add?

comments.text: The most profound aspect is this... the best listeners are not just patiently waiting for their turn to speak. They invest their time, energy, and mind in the exchange at that moment.

text:
Everyone wants the title.

Most quit when the scoreboard resets.

Here's 10 truths about being a 1st-time people leader that wasn't on my radar when I accepted the job:

1. The scoreboard resets. Yesterday‚Äôs technical wins?‚ÄØIrrelevant. Your team‚Äôs results are your new r√©sum√©.

2. Intent is invisible. People only feel what you actually say and do.

3. Clarity beats charisma. Vague vision delivered with flair still derails projects.

4. You can‚Äôt be everyone‚Äôs friend. Respect > likeability when the stakes rise.

5. Slow hires, fast fires. Your credibility erodes every day you keep the wrong player on the field.

6. Feedback is oxygen... breathe it or suffocate. Silence means blind spots.

7. Meetings are mirrors. Rambling agendas reveal fuzzy thinking at the top.

8. Culture is handcrafted daily. Each shortcut you tolerate becomes tomorrow‚Äôs norm.

9. You own the hard conversations. If you delegate them, you are the problem.

10. Leadership is a choice re‚Äëmade each morning. The moment you coast, the team follows.

Leadership isn‚Äôt a title but a daily practice of uncomfortable reps. 

Audit yourself against this list once a week. 

Keep what works, cut what doesn‚Äôt, and iterate. 

Because being a people leader means re‚Äëearning trust every Monday. Last week‚Äôs wins expire at 8‚ÄØAM.

comments.text: "You own the hard conversations. If you delegate them, you are the problem." So true. Though, most examples that I encountered in my life - people were just plain avoiding them.

text:
Most limits are self-imposed. 

95% of the time, just realizing that fact will help you push further.

comments.text: It's us that hold ourselves back from IMPORTANT, NOT URGENT, things. But "important" is an ambiguous term that can't be pinned down (i.e. it changes from day-to-day). Because of that ambiguity, we resist doing things that we know we SHOULD do but can't see an IMMEDIATE solution or consequence for. Doing ACTUAL "hard" things gives us the tools that make providing "important" things to ourselves and others easy.

text:
You don‚Äôt need better ideas. 

You need more guts.

This clip is a masterclass in creativity.

Mayer is committing. Fully. Even when the words are messy or half-formed, he stays in the flow. 

The trick is in having the courage to commit to imperfect lines in the moment. 

Bravery is the barrier to creativity.

Don‚Äôt wait for the perfect lyric, sentence, hook. 

Move. Write. Speak. Capture it raw, edit later.

If you‚Äôre creating anything, content, products, music, don‚Äôt aim to impress.
 
Aim to express.

And stay in the chair long enough to surprise yourself.

comments.text: This is amazing. Committing to imperfections in the moment is the key. Stay in the flow. Move, write, express.
"You need more guts." Yes, so very true. Just do it. World for sure is not going to end üòÜ

author.occupation: Engineering Leader | I Help Professionals Scale Up Their Impact | Insights on Growth, Leadership & AI

comments.text: Absolutely. Don‚Äôt wait for the ‚Äúright‚Äù moment, just dive in. Sometimes the best ideas are the ones that aren‚Äôt pretty at first!
Hits like a reminder we all need. Just have a crack, even if it‚Äôs a bit rough. Waiting for perfect is the quickest way to do nothing.

text:
Loud leaders steal the mic.

Quiet leaders win the game.

Everyone celebrates charisma, but in my experience the teams that actually outperform usually have a different kind of captain, one who leads with radar‚Äëlevel awareness instead of a bullhorn.

Here‚Äôs the eight‚Äëpoint playbook I wish someone had handed me ten years ago:

‚Ä¢¬†Shut up and tune in. Your people are closer to reality than any dashboard. Mine them for truth, not validation.

‚Ä¢¬†Make eye contact, not slide decks. Full attention is the rarest currency. Spend it generously.

‚Ä¢ Deliver consistently. Promises kept‚Äîquietly, relentlessly‚Äîgenerate compound interest in trust.

‚Ä¢¬†Whisper the win. A private ‚ÄúYou crushed that‚Äù sticks longer than a public fireworks show.

‚Ä¢¬†Absorb the chaos. When pressure spikes, be the human surge protector. Calm is contagious.

‚Ä¢¬†Hand over the keys. Autonomy is both the test and proof of trust. Pass it.

‚Ä¢¬†Ask for the human status update. ‚ÄúHow‚Äôs the workload?‚Äù is a checklist question. ‚ÄúHow are you really handling it?‚Äù is leadership.

‚Ä¢¬†Be the standard. Show up early, own the screw‚Äëups, sign your name to the result. Quiet leaders model; they don‚Äôt mandate.

If you want to go fast, talk. 
If you want to go far, listen.

Challenge for the week: In your next team meeting, speak last. 

Count how many insights surface before you ever open your mouth. 

Quiet might just be your loudest move.

comments.text: Love this! Leading quietly with intention really does make a bigger impact than shouting from the front.

text:
Most leaders marry the first playbook they read about, when reality already filed the divorce papers 10 years ago.

Problems outlive playbooks.

Strategies age, software sunsets, org charts reshuffle... but the underlying pain your team fights stays put.

Problems are X‚Äëray machines.

Start asking the right questions and you‚Äôll spot the blind spots; tiny fractures in your processes where morale is seeping through.

What single, gnarly challenge could you captain for the next 2 years, even if every tool in your kit changes? 

Write it down. 

Let every hire, metric, and strategy orbit that gravitational pull.

comments.text: 'Software sunsets' is the most poetical way I've heard someone talk about outdated programs. Beautiful.

text:
Everyone wants the secret to success, but most ignore the biggest lever: 
                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                    
consistency. 

Let's break it down in one image...     

Top picture: consistent effort. 

Small steps daily, boring but relentless. You‚Äôre always close enough to grab the next level.

Bottom picture: inconsistent effort. 

Huge bursts, big gaps. You‚Äôre stuck staring at that impossible jump after coming back from chasing the last shiny object that crossed your path, wondering why nothing ever works out.

Momentum is built through repetition. 

Progress is quiet, unsexy, and incremental. 

But the results are loud, and add up.

If you chase shiny objects, you‚Äôll burn out. 

Chase consistency, and you'll compound your way to places you never imagined possible. 

Choose wisely.

comments.text: Compounding everyday is essential. Iike your point about staring at the impossible jump. A good reminder to focus on the everyday wins, Swanagan Ray.

comments.text: Swanagan Ray Really appreciate how this breaks down the cost of inconsistency. Consistency might feel slow but it builds serious momentum over time. Quiet moves stack loud wins.

text:
Most teams don‚Äôt fail from lack of talent... 

They fail because people can‚Äôt see the movie playing in the leader's head.

When you‚Äôre the leader, context is your ultimate leverage. 

Spell out the destination and smart people will self-organize around the route. 

Hide the destination and you‚Äôll spend your life handing out turn-by-turn directions.

Tonight, draft a one-sentence plot summary for your team‚Äôs next six months. 

Tomorrow, open every meeting with that line. 

If your people can recite it back by Friday, you‚Äôve just installed a compounding advantage most companies will never touch.

text:
Most people quit the second the honeymoon ends.

That‚Äôs why the world is packed with dabblers and painfully short on masters.

Here's a simple litmus test:
If your effort doesn‚Äôt look boring to outsiders after six months, you‚Äôre still dabbling.

Here's a couple ways to flip the switch:

‚Ä¢¬†Build on long time horizons. Years and months. Not days or weeks.
‚Ä¢¬†Build a feedback lab. Record in a journal, review, refine. Every week. Non-negotiable.
‚Ä¢¬†System > mood. If the practice only happens when you feel inspired, you‚Äôre sunk.

The cost of mastery is monotony.

Don't be afraid to miss the next big thing.

Keep going.

text:
Your worst day now would‚Äôve felt like a vacation to the ‚Äúyou‚Äù from five years ago.

Swipe this mental map:

Local minima are the dips when a project stalls or a deal dies. Painful, yes, but still happening on a higher plane than your old problems.

Local maxima are the little wins... closing a client, hitting PR in the gym. Celebrate, but don‚Äôt unpack your bags.

Global maxima is the summit you can‚Äôt yet see because it lives beyond your current horizon of beliefs, skills, and network.

Every ascent rewires the baseline. 

Failures hurt, wins thrill, but your altitude keeps rising if you stay in the game. 

Mini-exercise for tonight:

Open your journal.

List last week‚Äôs lowest moment.

Under it, write three ways that ‚Äúlow‚Äù is actually higher than an old ‚Äúhigh‚Äù you once chased.

This micro-audit trains your brain to measure progress on an absolute scale, not a relative mood swing. 

Do it weekly and you‚Äôll start treating dips as data, not drama... and keep climbing toward the global peak that still feels impossible.

Stay optimal, keep climbing.

text:
Hot take: Your customer isn‚Äôt #1... 

Your employee is.

When leaders obsess over client happiness but ignore the people doing the work, they build a house on sand. 

Here‚Äôs the sturdier blueprint:

Safety first. 

Psychological safety lets employees escalate bad news fast, before it burns your client relationship.

Autonomy always. 

Micro-managed teams become ticket-takers. Empowered teams become problem-solvers who thrill customers without waiting for permission.

Growth on repeat. 

A learning budget beats a swag budget every time. When your people level up, so does the product the client touches.

Because when your team feels unstoppable, your customers feel it too.

text:
Most people audit their bank account, not their choices. 

That‚Äôs why their life balance stays overdrafted.

Quick reality check...

Every big win (or train wreck) you‚Äôve had can be traced back to a handful of micro-decisions:

‚Ä¢¬†What you say yes to on a day-by-day basis
‚Ä¢¬†What you ignore
‚Ä¢¬†Who you hang out with

Upgrade those levers and the rest of your ‚Äúluck‚Äù looks like a magic trick.

Here's a few ways to do it:

‚ñ† Create a 24-hour ‚Äúcooling period.‚Äù No commitments get ink until they survive until tomorrow‚Äôs coffee.
‚ñ† Run the 10-10-10 test. How will this choice feel in 10 minutes, 10 months, 10 years?
‚ñ† Keep a journal tracking your decisions. One line: decision + why. Review on Fridays; patterns will punch you in the face.
‚ñ† Adopt a mental board of directors. Before acting, ask, ‚ÄúWhat would [insert three mentors you admire] do?‚Äù

High-leverage living is just high-quality choosing on repeat.

Test one upgrade this week, measure the ripple, double down on what works, scrap what doesn‚Äôt. 

Small experiments, compounded relentlessly, build a life that feels engineered, not accidental.

comments.text: Love the 10-10-10 rule. Decision-making is a skill that can be developed and this is a great way to reflect on how your decisions impact you. Building an awareness of how you make decisions will lead to better choices with far-reaching effects. Great post Swanagan Ray.

text:
People chase flashy career hacks while the real power-ups are hidden in plain sight.

Here's 15 underrated leadership skills I've found to be invaluable:

1. Be ridiculously easy to work with‚Äîzero friction.
2. Happily be the least‚Äësmart person in the room.
3. Treat every single person with respect. 
4. Guard your calendar like it‚Äôs holding state secrets.
5. Obsess over outcomes, not optics or politics.
6. Always be on the lookout for people to help.
7. Write in simple, plain English (no jargon)
8. Lead with empathy.
9. Say ‚Äúno‚Äù more than yes. 
10. Stack skills that outgrow whatever title you hold.
11. Own your mistakes... immediately.
12. Follow up relentlessly until the loop is closed.
13. Always read between the lines. There‚Äôs a lot there.
14. Absorb the pressure, never punt it downstream.
15. Give credit where credit is due. And often.

Mastering a career is about tiny habits practiced consistently. 

Adopt even a few of these, and watch your influence compound quietly yet unmistakably over time.

comments.text: Love this list! It's the simple stuff, like treating people with respect and owning your mistakes, that really sets great leaders apart.

text:
The system trains you to follow the script your whole life. 

But your best life starts when you ignore it.

Most people live on autopilot.

Chasing checkboxes.

Playing roles they were handed. 

But you weren‚Äôt built for ‚Äúsupposed to.‚Äù You were built for meant to.

The spark that lights you up is your compass.

It doesn‚Äôt always make sense.
It doesn‚Äôt always pay well at first.
But it always knows where you‚Äôre supposed to go.

Skip the script.
Follow the spark.

Every meaningful path I‚Äôve followed started with a hunch I couldn‚Äôt explain.

And every regret came from ignoring it.

Trust the signal.
Even if it‚Äôs faint.

comments.text: Forget the script, life‚Äôs way more exciting when you‚Äôre chasing that spark instead of ticking boxes.
Scripts are for movies, not life! Follow that spark, even if it‚Äôs a little flicker, it‚Äôll lead you to the good stuff!

text:
Ever feel like an iPhone at 3% battery when you need to be a rocket at liftoff? 

Me too. 

Here's my cheat code to get from low-energy to peak-energy in seconds.

‚Ä¢¬†30 seconds of ice-cold water on your face. Instant adrenaline rush, no coffee required.
‚Ä¢¬†10 fast-paced push-ups or jumping jacks. Force your physiology awake.
‚Ä¢¬†Wim Hof-style breathing exercises for 60 seconds. It's like espresso for your brain.
‚Ä¢ A quick step and/or walk outside, fresh air and daylight immediately reset your mental state.
‚Ä¢¬†Your go-to high-tempo song.

Optimizing for energy is about creating rituals. 

So, experiment. 

Find the few that work for you, master them, and you'll always have control over your internal state.

comments.text: Swanagan, simple, science-backed, and actually doable. Energy isn‚Äôt just about rest; it‚Äôs about accessing your reserves with intention.¬†

text:
Most people jump from one shiny object to the next.

It may feel like movement, but really it's keeping you stuck as a dabbler...

Chasing novelty over boredom. 

I know this firsthand as a chronic dabbler. 

But I've found that real growth comes when you choose consistent action that compounds. 

Look at anyone great. 

Behind their mastery is a simple formula: pick something, stick with it, ride out the plateaus, and keep stacking skills... even when it gets boring.

Dabblers chase excitement. 
Masters chase depth. 
Depth compounds; excitement fades.

Here's what I ask myself when I feel the need to jump ship chasing the siren's song of excitement:

What am I currently dabbling in?
What would happen if I committed deeply to the one thing I'm already doing for a full year?

Try it yourself. 

And pick carefully...

Boredom just may become your superpower.

comments.text: not all movement is momentum! but i do think it's important to have some creative dabbling on the path to mastery

author.occupation: retail strategist ‚ú® sharing stories about stores in my free newsie ‚ú® previously @ warby parker & apple

comments.text: Consistency is where the magic happens. Skip the shiny objects and focus on one thing for long enough, and you'll be surprised at what you can achieve. Swanagan Ray

text:
Most ‚Äúleaders‚Äù aren‚Äôt leading. 

They‚Äôre managing checklists.

But if you want to build a real team, not just a group of people who report to you, master these 12 power moves:

1. Listen like it‚Äôs your job (because it is).
2. Trust first. Prove them right.
3. Be their shield.
4. Own your mistakes.
5. Reward process, not just results.
6. Cancel meetings that waste oxygen.
7. Say ‚Äúgreat job‚Äù in real time.
8. Treat flexibility like a necessity, not a luxury.
9. Budget for their growth. It‚Äôs ROI, not charity.
10. Write stuff down. Institutional memory matters.
11. Focus on culture, it‚Äôs everything.
12. Lead humans, not roles.

Anyone can push tasks.

Real leaders pull people forward.

What‚Äôs one of these you‚Äôre working on right now?

comments.text: Love this. Real leaders win by being human. It's their superpower.

text:
You'll rust out before you wear out.

Every master at anything was once terrible. And most weren't necessarily talented. 

But they were wiling to be boring. 

While everyone chases novelty, those that are successful stay the course and put in thousands of deliberate repetitions.

Here's 3 more principles I've observed in every master:
‚Ä¢ Consistent action beats waiting for readiness
‚Ä¢¬†Feedback is the chisel that shapes expertise
‚Ä¢¬†Improvement never stops, even at the peak

So why should you care? 

Because most people quit right before mastery happens. 

They give up at the exact moment consistent, boring practice would transform their results. 

The difference between good and great isn't some magical talent gene...

It's surviving the plateau long enough to break through to the next level.

comments.text: Mastery isn‚Äôt flashy, it‚Äôs just repetition with a dash of grit. Stick with it, the breakthrough‚Äôs coming!

text:
Hands shaking
Knees weak
Arms are heavy

Every single time I would get on stage or in front of a large group to speak, this would happen.

I used to hate it.

"This sucks. Why can't I just jump up there without getting super nervous?"

Then, I learned a reframe from I think a Simon Sinek video...

Nerves ‚â† fear
Nerves = fuel

My nerves weren't trying to sabotage me, they were trying to prime me.

Here's the biology behind it:

Your body doesn't differentiate between nerves and excitement. 

Both flood you with adrenaline. 

But if you just tell yourself that it's preparing you for battle, to crush it, and your mindset switches from fear to anticipation.

So crazy.

I could suddenly stand up and speak in front of huge crowds without scripts or notes. 

Sure, I still felt/feel it, but now I welcome that rush. 

It's my body's way of giving me an advantage.

Here's how I've made it stick:

Visualize success clearly before the big moment.
Remind yourself adrenaline means you're ready, not panicked.
Turn this into a ritual until excitement becomes your default setting.

Master this, and pressure becomes your playground.

comments.text: Love the perspective!

author.occupation: Data Evangelist | Digital Strategy Advisor | Helping Companies tackle the complex problem of contextualizing data to improve business performance

comments.text: Reframing nerves as fuel instead of fear is such a powerful mindset shift, it turns that nervous energy into an advantage. Thanks for sharing, Swanagan!

text:
Your "what" doesn't matter nearly as much as your "who."

The most successful people I know didn't succeed because they picked the perfect business model‚Ä¶

They succeeded because they built relationships with the right people.

Here's what I've learned about prioritizing "who" over "what":

The best business concept with no distribution channel will fail. An average idea with access to the right audience often succeeds.

Nearly every major break in my career came through someone I knew, not from submitting applications or cold outreach.

When I'm connected to crazy smart people, I make better decisions.

With the right connections, I can validate ideas faster and get immediate feedback.

When someone respected vouches for you, the trust they‚Äôve earned transfers to you instantly.

What does this mean practically?

Instead of asking "What business should I start?" or ‚ÄúWhat job should I take?‚Äù ask "How can I be the most valuable person in my network?‚Äù

Because once you are valuable to high-value people, they‚Äôll bring you along to their other networks. 

It compounds. 

Don't start with the product or the skills. 

Start with the people.

comments.text: So true. The right people open doors no strategy ever could.

resharedPost.text:
What‚Äôs the most underrated skill in the age of AI?

This came up during the The Careers Edit AI panel yesterday.

One of the points that landed most deeply for me in the conversation around AI, raised by Hashim Syed

was the emphasis on emotional intelligence as a critical skill for the future.

But I believe there‚Äôs something even more irreplaceable:

Presence.

The ability to be fully here. 
With others. With yourself.

To notice. 
To respond, not just react.

It‚Äôs what separates the good leaders from the exceptional.

Because when you‚Äôre truly present, you:

spot what others miss
ask better questions
create space for trust, creativity and clarity. 

And in a world run more and more by automation, it‚Äôs what will make you unforgettable and your leadership feel grounded and magnetic.

In the video I share why it matters now more than ever.

Curious to hear your take too!

What do you think is the most valuable skill in the AI era?

 - -

Hi, I‚Äôm Cristina founder of Play Big Careers.

I partner with mid-career professionals who are ready to get off autopilot, own their value and strengths and lead with greater presence.

I also deliver high-impact workshops that help leaders navigating change strengthen alignment, connection and purpose across their teams. 

Follow me for stories, insights and observations on how you can play BIG in your career without the hustle and overwhelm ü§∏üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

text:
Most people see these mega-brands and assume they started on top. 

It‚Äôs proof that your starting point doesn‚Äôt dictate your endpoint. 

Right now, you might be in a job that feels temporary or working on a product that‚Äôs miles from where you want it to be.

That‚Äôs okay. 

Because ‚Äúhumble‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean ‚Äústuck.‚Äù 

Everyone starts somewhere. You have to be a spud before you can be a stud. 

It just means you‚Äôre laying the foundation... one iteration, one pivot, one 1% improvement at a time.

Think of each day as an experiment. 

Test a small idea, refine it, then test again. 

Ultimately, these little improvements compound into a trajectory you never saw coming.

Your current situation might be your stepping stone to something far bigger... so why not take the next step?

text:
Most people approach leadership backwards.

They start by trying to influence others, but that‚Äôs the second step.

The first is influencing yourself.

Leadership is about trust, earned through consistent self-leadership: managing your emotions, mastering your discipline, aligning your actions with your values.

Once you master self-leadership, you naturally move toward servant leadership.

Servant leadership flips the script:

Instead of, "How do I get people to follow me?" You ask, "How can I serve people better with the skills and position that I have?"

When your team feels genuinely supported, they trust you.

And trust is the currency of real influence.

Great leaders develop influence by first mastering themselves, then serving others.

Start with you.

If you focus on mastering yourself and empowering others, influence, and real leadership, will follow.

comments.text: When you‚Äôve got control over yourself, serving others becomes a natural extension of that influence.

text:
Most people speak to be heard.

CEOs speak to be understood.

The difference?

Precision.

When a Fortune 500 CEO walks into a room, they‚Äôre not trying to prove how smart they are.

They‚Äôre trying to make complex ideas frictionless.

Here's what I've learned (from being lucky enough to work with a lot of high-horsepower CEOs) that they do differently:

1\ They open with the headline
No backstory. No context.
Just: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre losing $2.3M a month due to X. I have a fix.‚Äù
Then they explain.

2\ They kill jargon
Talk to your audience. These usually means no fluff. Do it in language your neighbor could understand.

3\ They pause on purpose
Silence is a weapon.
It signals confidence and gives people time to absorb key points.

4\ They speak in frameworks
‚ÄúWe have 3 levers: reduce cost, increase revenue, or improve retention.‚ÄùEverything flows from there.

5\ They answer the question before it's asked
They already know what the CFO, board, or VP is going to challenge, and they address it in the pitch.

6\ They focus on outcomes not activities
"We're implementing a new CRM system" vs. "We're cutting customer response time by 75%."
One focuses on activity, the other on impact.

Most people drown in details... CEOs distill.

At the end of the day, real power is being the one in the room who makes things simple.

comments.text: Great advice!
This is so important to understand, and so hard for many of us. Great post!

text:
Don‚Äôt be an idiot. 

The definition for idiot in Icelandic is ‚Äúsomeone that never leaves home to travel abroad‚Äù

To me, that is a metaphor for someone that never examines different perspectives or challenges their own beliefs. 

"The fact is that when two extreme opinions meet, the truth lies generally somewhere in the middle." - Annie Duke

Stop being afraid of looking like you were wrong.

Being wrong is just another opportunity to learn. And to find more truth.

Put your ideas out into the world and see what sticks. Engage with people that inhabit a different sphere of thought and belief. That different perspective will either solidify what you believe or make you

It's the best way to grow.

text:
Optimize for energy and joy. 

Everything else is a psyop.

Want proof?

Energy creates consistent action. Joy makes the journey sustainable. 

That's why it's so important to figure out what your zone of genius is, then build your career around that.

It's at the middle of the Venn diagram with 3 circles: what do you love to do, what are you good at, and what will people pay you for. 

Three questions I ask before any decision:
‚Ä¢¬†Will this give me energy or drain it?
‚Ä¢¬†Will this bring me genuine joy?
‚Ä¢ Will I regret not doing this?

Try this for one week. Watch what happens.

text:
I'll always remember what my Dad said: "You can't let difficult people have the power to ruin your day."

In my career I've dealt with every difficult type and learned that Dad was 100% right. 

The most valuable professional skill is the ability to work effectively with impossible people.

There's 3 principles that I've found helps with maintaining perspective in these difficult situations:

1. Their behavior reflects their limitations, not your worth
2. Decide what you will and won't tolerate before interactions
3. Not every difficult interaction requires intervention

You can't change difficult people. 

You can only change how you respond to them.

Because remember: 80% of your workplace stress comes from 20% of your relationships. 

Identify them.¬†
Manage them.¬†
Win.

text:
I don't think humans were meant to retire.

Retirement is a modern invention. 

For most of human history, people worked until they couldn't. Given, that was mostly out of necessity. But the right work also gives you purpose.

Traditional retirement is backwards.

We spend 40+ years doing work we don't like so we can finally do what we want when we're too old to fully enjoy it. 

This makes no sense.

The most miserable people I know are those who retired without purpose.

They achieved their goal of not working, but lost their sense of identity and contribution.

Conversely, those who never "retire" but transition to work they genuinely enjoy seem to live longer, happier lives.

To me this means don't stop working. 

Stop doing work that drains you.

I'll never retire. 

I'll keep writing, building, and creating until I physically can't anymore. 

Because I'm designing my work around what gives me energy rather than what takes it away.

If you're spending your days dreaming of retirement, you're solving the wrong problem. 

Don't escape work. Find better work.

comments.text: So true! It's not about avoiding work, it's about creating a life where your work brings you joy and meaning.

text:
Titles don't keep people at your company.
Sometimes money doesn't even keep people.

But, respect keeps people.

The math is simple:
Talent + Disrespect = Exit Plan

Real respect looks like:
‚Ä¢ Hearing ideas, not just rank
‚Ä¢ Building up, not tearing down
‚Ä¢ Trust over micromanagement

Want to know why your best people leave?

Look at how decisions get made.

Look at how feedback flows.

Look at who gets credit.

At the end of the day, people don't quit companies...
They quit cultures that diminish them.

Build a culture of respect.

‚ôªÔ∏è If you liked this, share it!
‚û°Ô∏è Follow me for more leadership insights.

text:
Stop focusing on the positive. 
                                                                                                                                          
At least all of the time. 

Great leaders aren't cheerleaders who only paint a picture of positivity. 

They're truth-tellers who can balance harsh reality with inspiring vision.

Every significant leadership failure I've witnessed shared one common trait: refusing to acknowledge reality while still pushing a grand vision. 

That disconnect breeds distrust.

The best leaders I know do two things exceptionally well:
‚Ä¢ State current reality with unflinching honesty
‚Ä¢¬†Keep the big vision constantly visible

Reality without vision creates disillusion. Vision without reality creates delusion.

The leadership question that's changed my approach forever: "What's true about our current situation that we're pretending isn't true?"

comments.text: Love this! True leadership is all about facing the facts while keeping the big picture in sight. You can't lead from fantasy‚Äîonly from reality.

comments.text: True leadership is acknowledging the brutal facts while maintaining unwavering faith in the bigger dream

comments.text: Balancing truth and vision is key.¬†

text:
Technical talent is everywhere. 

But technical people who can lead, communicate, and build relationships? They're rare. And they run the world.

After managing dozens of engineers and watching as many promotion cycles, I can tell you with absolute certainty that soft skills trump technical skills every single time when it comes to career advancement.

Want to be the person everyone wants to work with? 
Want to get that promotion this year instead of next? 

Here's what actually matters:

1. Active Listening
Most people wait to talk. They formulate their response while you're still speaking.

Great teammates genuinely listen. They ask clarifying questions. They summarize what they heard before responding.

Active listening builds trust faster than any other soft skill. When people feel understood, they become loyal advocates for you.

2. Clear Communication
A software engineer who can explain complex concepts simply is worth 3x one who can't.

Learn to adjust your message to your audience:
‚Ä¢ With executives, lead with the conclusion
‚Ä¢ With peers, focus on mutual benefits
‚Ä¢ With junior team members, explain the why

Next time you write an email or prepare for a meeting, spend 2 extra minutes thinking about your audience. It will save you hours of back-and-forth.

3. Problem Ownership
"That's not my job" is career suicide.

Problem owners find solutions regardless of whose fault it is. They don't need permission to make things better.

When something breaks, everyone looks to see who steps up. Be that person.

4. Strategic Thinking
Tactical employees solve today's problems. Strategic employees prevent tomorrow's problems.

Start asking:
"How will this scale?"
"What are the second-order consequences?"
"What risk am I not seeing?"

You know you've mastered this when leadership starts inviting you to roadmap discussions.

5. Reliability
The colleague who consistently delivers on time is more valuable than the brilliant one who delivers sporadically.

Reliability is simple but rare:
‚Ä¢ Say what you'll do
‚Ä¢¬†Do what you say
‚Ä¢¬†Communicate early when you can't

If you want to be indispensable, be the person everyone can count on.

Ultimately, technical skills might get you in the door, but soft skills get you promoted.

Lots of people never get this.

They keep grinding away at technical skills, wondering why they're passed over for promotions.

Ask yourself: If you were leading a team, would you promote the brilliant jerk or the solid performer who makes everyone around them better?

The decision is easy, and so is the path forward:

Pick one of these skills. 
Focus on it for 30 days. 
Once you've improved, move to the next.

And that's it!

text:
We all know those people...

The ones that are always negative, have an excuse for everything, and frankly are depressing to be around. 

This comes from learned helplessness. 

When you repeatedly fail and you feel like nothing is in your control, you stop trying. 

This happens through three specific beliefs:

1\ Permanence 
You believe the problem will last forever. Write this down: No problem is permanent, only your soul is permanent. Everything changes, everything eventually ends, and something new begins. Those are the seasons of life.

2\ Pervasiveness 
You believe one problem contaminates everything. Your relationship struggles don't make your entire life horrible. Remember what you still have: health, friends, work, or simply the ability to breathe.

3\ Personal 
You believe the problem exists because of who you are. "I'm not good enough. I'm not beautiful enough. I'm not smart enough." This becomes self-fulfilling when you stop trying.

These three P's have be destroyed if you want to make progress in relationships, career, happiness, or health.

In life, the powerful changes come from removing the mental barriers already in your way.

What I've found most effective: identify which P is your primary trap, then create a daily journal practice to write about and counter it. Even 60 seconds can begin rewiring these patterns.

Try this: For one week, at the same time each day, write down evidence that contradicts your dominant P. 

Your brain can't argue with your own proof.

Always remember: we suffer more in imagination than in reality.

comments.text: Stepping out of personalization, learning to externalize any issue and observe, is a skill desperately needed. Post to follow on that topic!

text:
I went from writing code to managing 30+ people in a weekend.

The brutal truth? 

I was almost a terrible leader. 

But I made these 12 mental shifts instead when I realized that the skills that got me here weren't the skills I needed to advance.

Most people focus on learning new skills when they hit a ceiling. 

‚Ä¢¬†Take more courses. 
‚Ä¢ They read more books. 
‚Ä¢¬†Collect more certifications.

But they're solving the wrong problem.

Your limiting beliefs are the invisible prison keeping you trapped at your current level. 

And they're far more powerful than any skill gap.

You have to dig deep and assess the stories you are telling yourself. And if they are helping you on the new level of the game, you have to cut them out. 

Mental shifts aren't about just thinking new thoughts, they're about using whole new patterns. 

And at the end of the day, you can't make these mental shifts, go back to being an IC. 

The world needs great individual contributors more than it needs mediocre leaders.

Your move.

comments.text: It's tough but rewarding when you realize it's more about mindset than certifications.

document.title: 7 Invisible Career Mistakes That Are Easy to Miss

text:
Don‚Äôt spend years climbing the wrong ladder.

I've seen many careers fail because of these 7 invisible mistakes. 

Fix them to instantly get ahead.

Mistake #1: Chasing Titles Instead of Skills 
‚û°Ô∏è Titles impress friends; skills impress employers. Prioritize growth over prestige.

Mistake #2: Ignoring Personal Branding 
‚û°Ô∏è Posting online is the new business card. Build your brand intentionally.

Mistake #3: Staying Comfortable 
‚û°Ô∏è Comfort kills careers. Choose challenges that stretch your abilities.

Mistake #4: Networking Only When Needed 
‚û°Ô∏è Relationships built in desperation rarely last. Build connections before you need them.

Mistake #5: Saying 'Yes' Too Often 
‚û°Ô∏è Protect your focus. Saying 'no' strategically is saying 'yes' to career clarity.

Mistake #6: Not Asking for Feedback 
‚û°Ô∏è Growth stalls when feedback stops. Regularly seek constructive criticism.

Mistake #7: Waiting for Permission 
‚û°Ô∏è Don't wait to be chosen. Take action first, seek permission later.

Apply these lessons ruthlessly. 

Life rewards those who subtract distractions, not just add skills.

comments.text: Great points! Building a strong personal brand and embracing feedback are key to continuous growth and staying ahead in your career.

text:
Giving good feedback is like being a surgeon: 

Precise, quick, and no unnecessary pain. 

Yet a lot of leaders swing feedback around like a blunt hammer. 

Here's how you can deliver feedback that's surgical and leaves people better off than you found them.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Do it in private

2Ô∏è‚É£ Clearly state what you're addressing. Don‚Äôt dance around the issue. Be direct but respectful.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Give clear, concrete examples to illustrate your points.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Explain the impact of their actions. Connect behavior directly to outcomes, showing why it matters.

Feedback without actionable steps is just criticism. 

Offer practical suggestions or alternatives to guide improvement.

Remember: the right words at the right time transform confusion into clarity.

comments.text:
Great analogy! Precise, thoughtful feedback builds trust and drives real improvement.

 Swanagan Ray

text:
Most people suck at making decisions.

Why?

They rely on gut feelings, vague advice, or copying what someone else did. 

That's like using a map from the 1950s to navigate today's roads.

Here‚Äôs a better way: mental models.

These are 5 models that have helped me simplify and clarify my decision-making:

1. 80/20 Principle: 80% of results come from 20% of efforts. Stop wasting time on things that barely move the needle.

2. First Principles: Break complex problems down to their fundamental truths. Rebuild your decision from the basics rather than copying others.

3. Inversion: Instead of asking "How can I win?", ask "How can I avoid losing?" Start by removing everything that guarantees failure.

4. If it's not an ABSOLUTE YES, it's a no: Avoid "good enough" options. Hold out for opportunities that truly excite you.

5. Even if it fails, can it still be a success?: Look for decisions that provide valuable lessons or build useful relationships, even if things don‚Äôt go as planned.

Remember, better decision-making about stacking the odds in your favor consistently.

What‚Äôs your go-to mental model?

text:
You know what's crazy? 

If you dropped dead tomorrow, your company would have your job posted faster than your family could pick a casket.

It‚Äôs easy as leaders to work long hours, weekends, and even on vacation.¬†
We glorify hustle culture, bragging about all of our unused vacation days like medals of honor. 

And I get it. 

The higher up the ladder you get, the more people rely on you and the more responsibility is on your shoulders. 

But your PTO balance isn't a trophy.

It just means you‚Äôre missing time with the people you love. 

Companies are machines built to survive, with or without you. So why prioritize a system that views you as replaceable over the moments that truly matter?

Work is important. And what you do matters. 

But you also have to prioritize time with the people in your life that matter the most. 

Here's a small challenge: this week, schedule that day off you've been delaying. Invest in yourself, your health, and your loved ones. Because in the end, no one ever said, "I wish I'd spent more time at the office.

comments.text: So true! Work will always be there, but those moments with loved ones? Not so much. Time to use that PTO and actually live a little!

text:
Everyone‚Äôs out here selling you ‚Äúthe way..."

But the uncomfortable truth is that you can't copy-paste success.

The career path, set of actions, etc that worked for someone else copied exactly will never give you the exact same outcome. 

You have a different operating system. 

The stuff that gives you energy will be different.
Motivations will be inherently different.
Your zone of genius is different. 

You have to experiment, fail, tweak, and repeat until something finally clicks.

It‚Äôs messy, frustrating, and humbling. But it‚Äôs also the only way to discover what actually works for you.

Don‚Äôt chase someone else‚Äôs playbook. 

Build your own.

Test relentlessly and trust your results.

Your success won't look exactly like anyone else‚Äôs... and that's exactly the point.

text:
Ever feel like you're drowning in to-dos and your day is a blur of half-started tasks? 

You‚Äôre not alone. 

I used to pride myself on doing a thousand things at once... until I realized none of them got done well. 

That‚Äôs when I switched from chasing ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù to focusing on efficacy. 

In other words, I got serious about doing the right things.

Life rarely unfolds in neat, predictable increments. 

The real difference-maker lies in consistent, meaningful action. 

By identifying the few critical steps that alleviate most of the day‚Äôs tension, you clear the path to a focused, productive schedule. 

If you can isolate what truly matters each morning and devote yourself to it, the rest tends to fall in line. 

This simple practice can radically shift your day from a chaotic sprint to a deliberate marathon, one task at a time.

text:
You can script the interview process all you want.

But, the best hires are the ones who break your script. 

If you‚Äôre tired of cardboard cutouts for candidates, it‚Äôs time to ask the kind of questions that demand realness‚Äîand spotlight who can lead in the trenches.

1Ô∏è‚É£ The ‚Äúreal talk‚Äù opener
Kick things off by setting a candid tone. 

For example: ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs forget the scripted Q&A. Tell me about the hardest conversation you‚Äôve had with a boss, and how you handled it.‚Äù 

You‚Äôll know right away if the candidate can deal with blunt honesty or if they‚Äôre just faking it.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Flip the script
My approach: Reserve one minute for the candidate to teach you something complex in simple terms, could be an obscure hobby or a technical skill. 

It shows how they handle the unexpected and gauge how well they communicate under stress.

3Ô∏è‚É£ The curveball question
My approach: Throw them a scenario that isn‚Äôt in the typical playbook. For instance: ‚ÄúYou have an underperformer on your team, but you suspect the real issue is they‚Äôre in the wrong role. How do you handle that conversation?‚Äù 

Genuine leaders will dig deeper into the root cause; pretenders will regurgitate boilerplate.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Be the student
My approach: Show humility and curiosity. Ask the candidate how they‚Äôd run your next all-hands or refine your onboarding process. See if they‚Äôd actually improve your organization. You‚Äôll quickly learn if they‚Äôre strategic or just reciting lines.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Reverse-engineer their curiosity
My approach: Toward the end, flip it: ‚ÄúNow‚Äôs your chance‚Äîwhat are the three biggest things on your mind about this role, our team, or the company?‚Äù 

High-quality questions reveal a critical thinker. 

If they come up empty, that‚Äôs your sign to keep looking.

Think of each tactic as a mini-experiment in human behavior, revealing who thrives under pressure and who‚Äôs just bluffing. 

Iterate, adapt, and you‚Äôll build a dream team that runs on trust, transparency, and drive.

comments.text: The best hires don‚Äôt just answer well, they challenge the conversation. Real leaders break the script

text:
There‚Äôs one book I recommend and gift more than any other:

‚ÄúSurely You‚Äôre Joking, Mr. Feynman‚Äù

Brilliant book.

It‚Äôs an autobiography, and it changed my life.

It showed me a way to live where you can be yourself, achieve greatness, and never lose a zeal for life.

There‚Äôs so many cool stories that illustrate Dr. Feynman‚Äôs ability to do this:

‚Ä¢¬†He used his understanding of rotation in physics to crack supposedly unbreakable safes at Los Alamos during the Manhattan Project.
‚Ä¢¬†He applied his physics knowledge to investigate the Challenger space shuttle disaster.
‚Ä¢¬†Obviously won the Nobel Prize for his work in quantum mechanics
‚Ä¢¬†And he was an accomplished drummer and painter.

It‚Äôs a wild book.

But my main takeaway was this:

Once you gain mastery in one sphere of competence, it‚Äôs exponentially easier to master the next thing.

Even if it‚Äôs in a totally different, unrelated skillset.

Feynman's approach to problem-solving often involved drawing insights from seemingly unrelated fields.

Why?

Because earning mastery in one area gives you a reference point.

Now, you know the level of effort, dedication, and persistence required.

You have realistic expectations. 

And this gifts you the mental fortitude needed to make it through the troughs of despair that you‚Äôll find in a new field.

Essentially, you‚Äôve learned how to learn.

But not just surface level learning.

You‚Äôve went down a rabbit hole and made it back out. So, when you go down that badger hole, you know what to expect (mostly).

Maybe even more importantly, success in one area builds confidence.

You have social proof now.

And no one can take that away.

comments.text: What you learn teaches you how to learn, a skill that will never go unused.

text:
The most impactful leader I ever worked with didn't have a fancy title or resume with the Ivy League on it. 

They just had rock-solid habits that made them irreplaceable.

The real superstars don‚Äôt always shine on the resume; they shine in subtle, everyday habits.

Here's a few of my favorites:

1\ Taking initiative
They don‚Äôt ask, ‚ÄúIs it okay if I fix this?‚Äù They just fix it.

2\ Listening more than they speak
‚Ü≥ They‚Äôre always the ones leaning in, absorbing ideas, and asking thoughtful follow-ups. 

3\ Showing empathy in real time
‚Ü≥ Quick check-ins, genuine questions, small gestures of support‚Äîthese folks defuse tension before it escalates. 

4\ Owning their mistakes
‚Ü≥ When they slip, they don‚Äôt dodge or deflect. They raise their hand and say, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs on me.‚Äù It‚Äôs a powerful signal of trustworthiness.

5\ Offering solutions; not just problems
‚Ü≥ Anyone can spot an issue. The real difference is the employee who walks in with ideas to tackle it.

6\ Underpromising and overdelivering
‚Ü≥ They set realistic deadlines, then blow you away by beating them. It‚Äôs the unflashy, consistent reliability that builds rock-solid reputations.

7\ Elevating the team‚Äôs win
‚Ü≥ They brag about their peers, not themselves. Leaders see that as a strong indicator of someone who will thrive in collaborative environments.

8\ Maintaining composure when it gets rough
‚Ü≥ Stress spikes, chaos ensues, and they remain unruffled. 

9\ Actively seeking feedback
‚Ü≥ Instead of waiting for reviews, they knock on doors asking for feedback. 

Don't think about these as box-checking. Think about making them a deliberate practice. 

Pick one or two that you vibe with, test them in your daily routines, and measure the impact. 

Reflect often. 
Tweak and iterate. 

Over time, these small actions compound.

The best part is that every step forward makes you not only a better teammate, but also a more capable leader.

comments.text: So true. Leadership shows up in the small, consistent habits.

text:
The smartest in the room wins, every time. 

That's what I used to think.

I was wrong. 

This piece of advice from a mentor changed my whole perspective:

"You'll go further with great people skills than you will with great engineering skills."

This advice, just as I was enrolling in engineering, came at the right time. 

I used to think knowing more than everyone else was the secret sauce. 

If I could just out-learn everyone, success was inevitable. 

But what I learned from Paul (and on the job) was that your technical expertise might get you a seat at the table, yet it‚Äôs your ability to communicate and connect that determines whether you actually get heard. 

I've watched brilliant engineers stall out, not because they lacked intelligence, but because they couldn‚Äôt translate complex ideas into everyday language.

At the end of the day, it‚Äôs relationships that power your career. 

Whether it‚Äôs building trust with a new client, steering your team through a meltdown, or simply pitching your next big idea, people skills unlock doors you didn‚Äôt even know existed.

Focus on the people in front of you. 

Identify their goals, their pain points, and how you can help them succeed. 

A small shift in how you communicate can lead to exponential growth in your impact. 

Over time, you‚Äôll see that mastering the human side can carry you further than anything else.

comments.text: Smart teams get stuck when brilliance can't connect. The engineer who speaks human creates more impact than ten technical experts.

text:
Lots of leaders drown in details and forget the ocean they‚Äôre swimming in. 

But if you don‚Äôt define the north star for your organization, guess what? 

No one else will. 

A rock-solid vision sets the stage for the whole organization.

It's dangerously easy to slip into checklists and chores because they feel safe. 

But the best leaders step beyond the comfort of small tasks. 

They know the true work is defining (and defending) the big picture. 

That means carving out time to remind yourself, and your people, of the north star. All the rules, processes, and daily friction? They support the mission, not the other way around.

The beauty of keeping the main thing the main thing is that it cuts through the clutter. 

When everyone rallies around a singular, well-defined purpose, you sidestep a lot of ‚ÄúWhat are we actually doing here?‚Äù anxiety. 

The goalposts become unmistakably clear, making it far easier to guide your organization toward meaningful outcomes.

So, next time you feel buried under the small stuff, ask: ‚ÄúDoes this align with the main mission?‚Äù If yes, keep it. If not, set it aside. 

The greatest resource you have is focus.

Ultimately, leadership is about choosing the vital over the trivial. 

And if you do it right, you‚Äôll discover that the real superpower of focus is more freedom, not less.

comments.text: Love this‚Äîclarity isn‚Äôt just a luxury, it‚Äôs a leadership necessity. Keep the vision sharp, and the rest falls into place!

text:
Small vision. 

Small results.

The biggest myth killing your success? Thinking vision is just a mission statement.

Here are 7 vision-killing beliefs holding you back... debunked:

1. "Vision is just a fancy mission statement"
Wrong.
Vision is your blueprint for disruption.
It's what you see that others don't.

2. "You need to have it all figured out"
False.
The best visions evolve.
Amazon started with books.
Now they're in space.

3. "Vision is the CEO's job"
Dangerous thinking.
Every great innovator started somewhere.
Usually not at the top.

4. "Market research is enough"
Data shows what is.
Vision shows what could be.
Big difference.

5. "Keep your vision realistic"
Translation: Stay small.
Every game-changing company started with an "unrealistic" vision.

6. "Wait until you're ready"
You'll wait forever.
Vision without action is just daydreaming.
Start before you feel ready.

7. "Don't change your vision"
Dead wrong.
The best leaders adapt their vision.
They just never lose sight of impact.

Truth: Your vision isn't just about you.
It's about the change you're brave enough to create.

What's stopping you from thinking bigger?
